title: 'Discrimination based on nationality': backpacker tax ruled invalid
text:
Working holidaymakers are subject to a 15 per cent tax on their first $37,000 of income in Australia, while Australian citizens who are tax residents enjoy have a tax-free threshold on income up to $18,200.

Citizens from the eight countries account for about 50 per cent of all visitors to Australia on the relevant visa categories.

The test case was supported by international accounting firm TaxBack.com.

Chief executive Joanna Murphy said the decision was an important protection for foreign citizens choosing to work while holidaying in Australia.

“In our view it was very clear when the tax was introduced in 2016 that it discriminated against foreign workers and breached several international tax agreements.

"It also damaged Australia’s reputation as a working holiday destination,” Ms Murphy said.

Declining numbers of backpackers have hurt some regional businesses, reliant on their estimated $3.5 billion in economic activity annually.

Arnold Bloch Leibler partner Clint Harding said the case further exemplified a complicated web of concepts covering tax residents, temporary residents and working holiday makers.

"While the courts are doing an admirable job in trying to pull a lot of these seemingly disparate threads together, I think it is impossible for anyone to say that the law is clear in this area.

"In my view uncertainty prevails and should be addressed. It is getting to the point where it is becoming embarrassing for all of those involved in advising on, and indeed administering, issues concerning tax residency," he said.

Australia's richest person, Visy boss Anthony Pratt, called on the government to scrap the backpackers' tax to help improve economic conditions for primary producers.

"Let's look at eliminating the backpackers' tax. It's one thing our farmers have said to me," Mr Pratt said in November 2018.

"This is essential if we're to ensure that no fruit is left behind because of a lack of labour to pick it."

Treasurer Josh Frydenberg has been contacted for comment.
description: A Federal Court judge has ruled the government's backpacker tax is invalid, calling it a disguised form of discrimination.
